user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_rename:
```c
int32 OS_rename(const char *old, const char *new)
{
    OS_object_iter_t             iter;
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;
    int32                        return_code;
    char                         old_path[OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN];
    char                         new_path[OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN];

    return_code = OS_TranslatePath(old, old_path);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_TranslatePath(new, new_path);
    }

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_FileRename_Impl(old_path, new_path);
    }

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdIterateActive(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, &iter);

        while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
        {
            stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, iter.token);

            if (stream->socket_domain == OS_SocketDomain_INVALID && strcmp(stream->stream_name, old) == 0)
            {
                strncpy(stream->stream_name, new, sizeof(stream->stream_name) - 1);
                stream->stream_name[sizeof(stream->stream_name) - 1] = 0;
            }
        }

        OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_rename:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_stream_internal_record_t OS_stream_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    char   stream_name[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    uint8  socket_domain;
    uint8  socket_type;
    uint16 stream_state;
} OS_stream_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    OS_common_record_t * base;
    OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t match;
    void *               arg;
    osal_index_t         limit;
    OS_object_token_t    token;
} OS_object_iter_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdIterateActive(osal_objtype_t objtype, OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    return OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_ObjectFilterActive, NULL, objtype, iter);
}
...
bool OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    bool                got_next;

    got_next           = false;
    iter->token.obj_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

    do
    {
        ++iter->token.obj_idx;
        if (iter->token.obj_idx >= iter->limit)
        {
            break;
        }

        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(iter->base, iter->token);
        if (iter->match == NULL || iter->match(iter->arg, &iter->token, record))
        {
            iter->token.obj_id = record->active_id;
            got_next           = true;
        }
    } while (!got_next);

    return got_next;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(&iter->token);
}
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN (OS_MAX_PATH_LEN+OS_FS_PHYS_NAME_LEN)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I examined all code fragments (the OS_rename function and the related definitions). I found no uses of compiler-specific language extensions as typically documented as extensions (e.g., GCC __attribute__ annotations, __asm__, typeof, statement-expressions, nested functions, GCC __extension__ keywords, nonstandard pragma usages, compiler-specific keywords, anonymous structs/unions as an extension, or implicit zero-length/flexible-array hacks). Specific notes to justify not flagging fragments:

- Macro usage (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) -> (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])): This is standard preprocessor/macro usage and uses the address-of operator; not a compiler extension.
- static inline function (static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(...)): The inline keyword is standard in C99 and later; it is not a compiler extension by itself. If a particular compiler documents inline as an extension, that would need explicit evidence in the compiler docs before flagging.
- Use of standard library routines (strcmp, strncpy): These are standard C library functions, not language extensions.
- Fixed-width-like typedefs and integer names (int32, uint8, uint16): These are typedefs/aliases defined elsewhere in the codebase; typedefs are standard C, not compiler extensions.
- Use of bool: This is standard C99 (stdbool.h) or could be a typedef; neither is inherently a compiler extension.
- Pre- and post-increment operators, struct member access, array indexing, pointer operations: All are standard C constructs.

Because none of the constructs in the provided code are compiler-specific extensions as typically documented (and no compiler-specific identifiers/attributes/pragmas are present), there are no fragments to report for further investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
